For every positive integer $n$, let $\text{mod}_5 (n)$ be the remainder obtained when $n$ is divided by 5. Define a function $f: \{0,1,2,3,\dots\} \times \{0,1,2,3,4\} \to \{0,1,2,3,4\}$ recursively as follows:

\[f(i,j) = \begin{cases}\text{mod}_5 (j+1) & \text{ if } i = 0 \text{ and } 0 \le j \le 4 \text{,}\\ f(i-1,1) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } j = 0 \text{, and} \\ f(i-1, f(i,j-1)) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } 1 \le j \le 4. \end{cases}\]What is $f(2015,2)$?

0.user_question:
For every positive integer $n$, let $\text{mod}_5 (n)$ be the remainder obtained when $n$ is divided by 5. Define a function $f: \{0,1,2,3,\dots\} \times \{0,1,2,3,4\} \to \{0,1,2,3,4\}$ recursively as follows:

\[f(i,j) = \begin{cases}\text{mod}_5 (j+1) & \text{ if } i = 0 \text{ and } 0 \le j \le 4 \text{,}\\ f(i-1,1) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } j = 0 \text{, and} \\ f(i-1, f(i,j-1)) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } 1 \le j \le 4. \end{cases}\]What is $f(2015,2)$?

subanswer.text: Using recursive calls starting at step zero, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\quad\ f(2015, 2)=\\&\qquad f(2014,1)=\quad\quad f(2013,f(2014,0))=\\&\qquad \qquad\ f(2013,1)=\quad\quad f(2012,f(2013,1))=\\&\qquad\ \ \ \ \ \vdots\\&\quad\quad\cdots f(2,f(3,0)),\end{aligned}\] so after evaluating enough terms using substitution backwards until reaching some base case like $f(base\_case,some \,number)$, we end up computing $$f(2015,2)=\text{mod}_5(7),$$ where $\text{mod}_5(7)$ denotes modulo operation which calculates the remainder upon division of $7$ by $5$. Thus, since any multiple of five plus seven leaves a residue or 'remainder' of 2 under modular arithmetic ($\equiv\,2\,\pmod{5}$ ), our final computation yields $$\boxed{\text{mod}_5(7)=2}$$as expected due to closure property over field of integers within range [0..4]. The answer is $2$.

For every positive integer $n$, let $\text{mod}_5 (n)$ be the remainder obtained when $n$ is divided by 5. Define a function $f: \{0,1,2,3,\dots\} \times \{0,1,2,3,4\} \to \{0,1,2,3,4\}$ recursively as follows:

\[f(i,j) = \begin{cases}\text{mod}_5 (j+1) & \text{ if } i = 0 \text{ and } 0 \le j \le 4 \text{,}\\ f(i-1,1) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } j = 0 \text{, and} \\ f(i-1, f(i,j-1)) & \text{ if } i \ge 1 \text{ and } 1 \le j \le 4. \end{cases}\]What is $f(2015,2)$?

ost_step.1: Start evaluating the recursive definition beginning with smaller subproblems until reaching our target problem ($f(2015,2)$):
ost_step.2: Evaluate $f(2015,2)$ using recursion: since both parameters satisfy conditions "$i \ge 1$" and "$1 \le j \le 4$," apply condition three ("if $$$$$$\\textit{$i$} \\ge \\textit{1}$$$$$$ and $$\$\textit{$j$} \\ne \\textit{0}$$$$$$ or else"). Thus, $f(2015,2)=f(2014,f(2015,1))$=...=$f(2014,f(2014,f(2013,2)))$=…($f(2014,19)$$)\cdots(\textbf{condition one satisfied})=1.$ Using similar steps through further nestings yields $f(2015,2)=f(2014,19)...f(2007,1)=\text{ mod}_5 (19)+1.$$\because\, \, \$f(k,m)$ maps into $\{0,...,4\}$,and hence so does any term derived via application of condition three.'Thus:\\text{for each iteration, increment m}, but
ost_step.3: Note that during nested evaluation you increase your inner argument by exactly five due to applying condition three repeatedly; additionally decrement outer parameter k once upon completion of the innermost loop—effectively iterating over multiples of 5 upwards without limit.<|im_sep|>So,$f(2015,2)\\Rightarrow\quad f(2014,19)\\Rightarrow\quad f(2013,2)=\text{mod}(2013+19,5)}$ [Apply condition three], ... , … .$\\Rightarrow\quad f(2,2)=\text{mod}(1+1,5)=\text{mod}(2,5)=2.$This last statement was reached within six iterations:$f(2015,2)=\text{mod}(2015+1,5)=\text{mod}(2016,5)=1.$We note that it also could have been evaluated more efficiently had instead applied condition zero directly (since no base cases met); however, having done sufficient work towards understanding how different parts interact led us here quicker overall.</|end_of_solution|>In solving problems involving functions defined piecewise like in Example

direct_answer.text:
